explanation: Official Declaration 2 affirms that priesthood ordination is available to all worthy male members without regard to race or color and that temple blessings are available to all faithful members.

topic: Diversity and Unity in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
question_text: Which principle, taught in the Doctrine and Covenants, guides the Church in making decisions and sustaining leaders in a way that fosters unity among diverse members?
answers: Common consent (all things to be done by common consent, by prayer and faith)
Majority-rule political caucus
Clerical infallibility
Secret ballot without public sustaining
correct_answer: Common consent (all things to be done by common consent, by prayer and faith)
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 26:2 teaches that all things in the Church are to be done by common consent, by much prayer and faith, underpinning the practice of sustaining leaders and decisions.

question_text: Which statement best reflects the Church’s official position on divorce?
answers: The Church discourages divorce and urges couples to work to resolve difficulties, but acknowledges that some marriages cannot be saved and divorce may be necessary.
Divorce is always a sin requiring excommunication.
Divorce is prohibited under all circumstances.
Divorce permanently bars members from temple worship.
correct_answer: The Church discourages divorce and urges couples to work to resolve difficulties, but acknowledges that some marriages cannot be saved and divorce may be necessary.
explanation: Official Church materials teach that while marriage should be preserved where possible, some marriages cannot be saved and divorce may be necessary; divorced members may continue to participate in the Church according to their worthiness.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint practice, what is the effect of a civil divorce on a prior temple sealing?
answers: A civil divorce does not automatically cancel a temple sealing; a cancellation of sealing or sealing clearance must be requested and approved by the First Presidency.
A civil divorce automatically cancels the sealing when the decree is final.
The temple presidency where the sealing occurred may cancel it at their discretion.
The sealing cancels itself after one year if neither party requests otherwise.
correct_answer: A civil divorce does not automatically cancel a temple sealing; a cancellation of sealing or sealing clearance must be requested and approved by the First Presidency.
explanation: According to the General Handbook, only the First Presidency may grant a cancellation of sealing or a sealing clearance; a civil divorce alone does not end a temple sealing.

question_text: How does divorce affect a member’s eligibility for a temple recommend?
answers: Divorce itself does not automatically affect eligibility; members may hold a recommend based on personal worthiness, as determined in a standard interview.
Divorced members are ineligible for a recommend for at least one year.
Divorced members may hold a recommend only if they have no minor children.
A divorce always requires a membership council before a recommend can be issued.
correct_answer: Divorce itself does not automatically affect eligibility; members may hold a recommend based on personal worthiness, as determined in a standard interview.
explanation: Official policy bases temple recommend eligibility on personal worthiness; divorce alone is not grounds for restricting participation or for automatic discipline.

question_text: In the Doctrine and Covenants, which section contains the revelation known as the Word of Wisdom?
answers: D&C 89
D&C 76
D&C 58
D&C 27
correct_answer: D&C 89
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 89 contains the Word of Wisdom, a health code revealed to Joseph Smith on February 27, 1833, as noted in the section heading.

question_text: Which section is designated as 'the Lord’s preface' to the Doctrine and Covenants?
answers: D&C 1
D&C 4
D&C 20
correct_answer: D&C 1
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 1 is titled 'The Lord’s Preface' in its section heading, given November 1, 1831, as an introduction to the revelations.

question_text: The revelation outlining the organization and government of the Church, known as the 'Articles and Covenants of the Church,' is found in which section of the Doctrine and Covenants?
answers: D&C 20
D&C 42
D&C 28
D&C 90
correct_answer: D&C 20
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 20, often called the Articles and Covenants, sets forth foundational organization, offices, and ordinances of the Church (April 1830).

question_text: According to Latter-day Saint doctrine, what central event does Easter commemorate?
answers: The bodily Resurrection of Jesus Christ on the third day
The birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem
The Ascension of Jesus Christ into heaven
The Transfiguration of Jesus on the mount
correct_answer: The bodily Resurrection of Jesus Christ on the third day
explanation: Easter commemorates Jesus Christ's Resurrection (see Matthew 28; Luke 24; 1 Corinthians 15; Alma 11; 3 Nephi 11).

question_text: In the Book of Mormon account following Jesus Christ's Resurrection, where did He first appear to the gathered people in the Americas?
answers: At the temple in the land Bountiful
In the city of Zarahemla
At the hill Cumorah
In the land of Nephi
correct_answer: At the temple in the land Bountiful
explanation: 3 Nephi 11:1–10 records that the resurrected Christ appeared at the temple in the land Bountiful and ministered to the people.

question_text: Which statement best describes how The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints observes Easter?
answers: Members worship on Easter Sunday in regular sacrament meetings focused on the Resurrection, often with Christ-centered sermons and music; there is no mandated Lent or Holy Week liturgy.
Members are required to observe a 40-day fast (Lent) before Easter as a churchwide policy.
The Church holds mandatory Good Friday and Holy Saturday services with sacraments distinct from the weekly sacrament.
Administration of the sacrament is suspended on Easter Sunday.
correct_answer: Members worship on Easter Sunday in regular sacrament meetings focused on the Resurrection, often with Christ-centered sermons and music; there is no mandated Lent or Holy Week liturgy.
explanation: The Church does not prescribe a formal Lent or Holy Week; local Easter Sunday sacrament meetings emphasize Christ's Resurrection (see General Handbook, 'Sacrament Meeting'; ChurchofJesusChrist.org topic pages on Easter).

question_text: Which scripture contains the counsel to 'seek learning, even by study and also by faith'?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 88:118
2 Nephi 9:29
Proverbs 4:7
Articles of Faith 1:13
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 88:118
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 88:118 explicitly teaches to seek learning by both study and faith, a foundational LDS principle about education.

question_text: Seminary in the Church Educational System is primarily designed for which age group?
answers: Primary children (ages 8–11)
Young women and young men ages 12–13
High school–age youth (generally ages 14–18)
Young single adults (ages 18–30)
correct_answer: High school–age youth (generally ages 14–18)
explanation: Seminary is a four-year religious education program for high school–age Latter-day Saint youth, typically covering Old Testament, New Testament, Book of Mormon, and Doctrine and Covenants/Church History.

question_text: Who announced the Perpetual Education Fund (PEF) and in what year?
answers: President Gordon B. Hinckley in 2001
President Thomas S. Monson in 2008
Elder Jeffrey R. Holland in 1999
President Russell M. Nelson in 2018
correct_answer: President Gordon B. Hinckley in 2001
explanation: President Gordon B. Hinckley announced the Perpetual Education Fund in the April 2001 general conference to help young adults obtain education and job training.

question_text: To which priesthood does the office of elder belong in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
answers: The Melchizedek Priesthood
The Aaronic Priesthood
The Levitical Priesthood
The Patriarchal Priesthood
correct_answer: The Melchizedek Priesthood
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 107:7 teaches that the office of elder belongs to the Melchizedek Priesthood.

question_text: According to scripture, which ordinance is an elder authorized to perform by the laying on of hands?
answers: Confirming and bestowing the gift of the Holy Ghost
Sealing marriages for time and eternity
Setting apart a bishop to preside over a ward
Performing washing and anointing ordinances in the temple
correct_answer: Confirming and bestowing the gift of the Holy Ghost
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 20:41, 43 lists confirming those baptized and giving the Holy Ghost as duties of elders.

question_text: In official Church usage, which group is addressed by the title "Elder"?
answers: Male full-time missionaries
Female full-time missionaries
Bishops of local wards
Members of the Relief Society General Presidency
correct_answer: Male full-time missionaries
explanation: Official Church style and missionary standards designate male missionaries as "Elder"; female missionaries are addressed as "Sister."

question_text: Which statement best reflects the Church’s basic counsel on home storage and emergency preparedness?
answers: Begin by building a small supply of food and water and some money in savings; then expand your storage gradually.
Purchase a full one-year supply immediately, even if it requires going into debt.
Focus only on long-term grains; fresh foods are discouraged.
Store only water; food storage is no longer recommended.
correct_answer: Begin by building a small supply of food and water and some money in savings; then expand your storage gradually.
explanation: Official guidance (e.g., All Is Safely Gathered In) teaches to start small—food, water, and some savings—and build gradually; avoid debt.

question_text: In a local emergency, who is responsible for assessing needs and coordinating relief within a ward according to the Church’s General Handbook?
answers: The bishop, working with the elders quorum and Relief Society presidencies under the direction of the stake president.
The Sunday School president.
The full-time missionaries acting independently.
Individual members without coordination from leaders.
correct_answer: The bishop, working with the elders quorum and Relief Society presidencies under the direction of the stake president.
explanation: The General Handbook assigns bishops responsibility for members’ temporal welfare and for coordinating ward emergency response with elders quorum and Relief Society, under stake direction.

question_text: Which of the following is included in Church counsel for personal emergency preparedness?
answers: Create and practice a simple family emergency plan, including communication methods and meeting places.
Expect that ward leaders will provide all needed supplies during any emergency.
Plan to go into debt to purchase all emergency supplies at once.
Ignore directions from civil authorities and wait only for Church instructions.
correct_answer: Create and practice a simple family emergency plan, including communication methods and meeting places.
explanation: Church materials on emergency preparedness counsel families to make and practice a simple plan and to follow civil authorities; members should avoid debt and be personally prepared.

question_text: In a ward-level emergency affecting members, who is responsible for directing the Church’s immediate response and welfare efforts?
answers: The bishop
The elders quorum president
The Relief Society president
The Area Seventy
correct_answer: The bishop
explanation: The bishop has primary responsibility for the welfare of ward members and directs ward-level emergency response under the direction of the stake president, per the General Handbook’s sections on welfare and emergencies.

question_text: According to Church policy, under what circumstances may a meetinghouse be used as a public shelter during a disaster?
answers: Only when coordinated with local civil authorities and approved by appropriate Church leaders
Whenever a member offers the building
Never under any circumstances
Automatically whenever the Red Cross requests it
correct_answer: Only when coordinated with local civil authorities and approved by appropriate Church leaders
explanation: The General Handbook and meetinghouse use policies state that meetinghouses are not general public shelters but may be used as shelters when coordinated with civil authorities and approved by Church leaders.

question_text: What is the primary source of funds a bishop uses to provide immediate temporal assistance to ward members after an emergency?
answers: Fast offerings
Tithing funds
Ward missionary fund
Humanitarian aid donations
correct_answer: Fast offerings
explanation: Fast offerings are designated for caring for the poor and needy at the local level; bishops use them to meet immediate member needs, including after disasters, as outlined in the General Handbook’s welfare principles.

question_text: Which statement best describes the Church's policy regarding pay for local lay leaders such as bishops and stake presidents?
answers: They serve without pay; local leadership is a lay ministry.
They receive a salary funded by tithes and offerings.
They are paid only if their congregation exceeds certain size thresholds.
They are compensated for Sunday meeting hours only.
correct_answer: They serve without pay; local leadership is a lay ministry.
explanation: Local leaders serve without pay as part of the Church’s lay ministry. This is an established, official policy of the Church.

question_text: What is a primary purpose of Deseret Industries, operated by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
answers: To provide training and work experience that help people gain employment.
To offer interest-free cash grants to members for personal expenses.
To publish official Church curriculum materials.
To function as a for-profit retail chain to generate income for the Church.
correct_answer: To provide training and work experience that help people gain employment.
explanation: Deseret Industries functions as a job training and rehabilitation program, offering work experience and skills development to help individuals become self-reliant and employed.

question_text: Which Church resource is specifically designed to help individuals find employment through coaching, workshops, and networking?
answers: Employment Services (Self-Reliance Services) of the Church
FamilySearch
JustServe
Seminaries and Institutes of Religion
correct_answer: Employment Services (Self-Reliance Services) of the Church
explanation: Employment Services, part of the Church’s Welfare and Self-Reliance efforts, provides job-seeking assistance, coaching, and networking resources.

question_text: According to official Church teachings, what is the primary purpose of the temple endowment?
answers: To receive instruction, make covenants with God, and be endowed with power from on high
To memorize historical dates from Church history
To replace baptism and confirmation as saving ordinances
To publicly declare faith before a congregation
correct_answer: To receive instruction, make covenants with God, and be endowed with power from on high
explanation: The endowment provides instruction about God’s plan, includes sacred covenants, and fulfills the Lord’s promise to endow His people with power from on high.

question_text: Which of the following is required before a member may receive his or her own temple endowment?
answers: Holding a current temple recommend issued after worthiness interviews
Having received a patriarchal blessing
Receiving a mission call
Being sealed in the temple to a spouse
correct_answer: Holding a current temple recommend issued after worthiness interviews
explanation: A current temple recommend, obtained through interviews with priesthood leaders, is required to receive the endowment; the other options are not requirements.

question_text: In this dispensation, when and where did Joseph Smith first administer the temple endowment to a small group of Saints?
answers: May 4, 1842, in the upper room of the Red Brick Store in Nauvoo, Illinois
March 27, 1836, in the Kirtland Temple, Kirtland, Ohio
April 6, 1830, at the organization meeting in Fayette, New York
December 27, 1847, in Winter Quarters, Nebraska
correct_answer: May 4, 1842, in the upper room of the Red Brick Store in Nauvoo, Illinois
explanation: Joseph Smith first administered the full Nauvoo-era endowment on May 4, 1842, in the Red Brick Store; this is well documented in Church history sources.

question_text: Which New Testament verse explicitly states, "he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved"?
answers: Matthew 24:13
James 1:5
Romans 10:9
1 Corinthians 15:29
correct_answer: Matthew 24:13
explanation: In the Olivet Discourse, Jesus promises salvation to those who endure to the end (Matthew 24:13).

question_text: According to 2 Nephi 31:20, which phrases describe the manner of pressing forward while enduring to the end?
answers: "a perfect brightness of hope" and "a love of God and of all men"
"mighty change of heart" and "born of God"
"faith unfeigned" and "pure religion"
"stand in holy places" and "choose the right"
correct_answer: "a perfect brightness of hope" and "a love of God and of all men"
explanation: 2 Nephi 31:20 lists these phrases along with feasting on the word of Christ and promises eternal life to those who endure.

question_text: In the Book of Mormon’s doctrine of Christ (2 Nephi 31), enduring to the end is taught to follow which ordinances?
answers: Baptism and receiving the Holy Ghost
Temple endowment and sealing
Ordination to the priesthood and setting apart
Anointing with oil and washing of feet
correct_answer: Baptism and receiving the Holy Ghost
explanation: Nephi teaches the sequence of faith, repentance, baptism, receiving the Holy Ghost, and then enduring to the end (2 Nephi 31:13–20).

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 59:18–20, how should God's creations and earthly resources be used?
answers: With gratitude and judgment, not in excess or by extortion, to please the eye and gladden the heart
Only for basic survival; aesthetic enjoyment is discouraged
Without restriction, since resources are unlimited
Solely by those holding priesthood office
correct_answer: With gratitude and judgment, not in excess or by extortion, to please the eye and gladden the heart
explanation: D&C 59:18–20 teaches that all things are made for the benefit and use of man—"to please the eye and to gladden the heart"—and are to be used with judgment, not to excess nor by extortion.

question_text: What counsel does the Church’s official Gospel Topics entry "Environmental Stewardship and Conservation" give to members?
answers: Gratefully use resources, avoid waste, and care for the earth for future generations
Leave environmental care solely to governments and advocacy groups
Withdraw from modern society to reduce personal impact
Focus only on spiritual matters; material creation is secondary
correct_answer: Gratefully use resources, avoid waste, and care for the earth for future generations
explanation: The official topic page teaches that all are stewards over the earth and should use resources wisely, avoid waste, and preserve the environment for the benefit of the poor and future generations.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 104:14, who is the ultimate owner of the earth and its fulness?
answers: The Lord
Humanity collectively
National governments
No one; it is unowned
correct_answer: The Lord
explanation: D&C 104:14 declares, "the earth is mine, and the fulness thereof," affirming God’s ownership and our stewardship.

question_text: Which New Testament verse explicitly defines "life eternal" as knowing God the Father and Jesus Christ?
answers: John 17:3
Romans 6:23
1 Corinthians 15:20–22
Revelation 20:12
correct_answer: John 17:3
explanation: John 17:3 states, "And this is life eternal, that they might know thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom thou hast sent."

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 14:7, what is "the greatest of all the gifts of God"?
answers: Resurrection
Eternal life
The priesthood
A remission of sins
correct_answer: Eternal life
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 14:7 identifies the gift of eternal life as the greatest of all the gifts of God.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint doctrine, what is the correct distinction between immortality and eternal life?
answers: Immortality is living forever after resurrection; eternal life is living forever in God's presence (exaltation).
Immortality and eternal life are identical terms with no doctrinal difference.
Immortality is living in the telestial kingdom; eternal life is living in the terrestrial kingdom.
Immortality is spiritual rebirth; eternal life is physical resurrection.
correct_answer: Immortality is living forever after resurrection; eternal life is living forever in God's presence (exaltation).
explanation: Official Church resources teach that immortality is resurrection to endless life, while eternal life is exaltation—life with God in His presence (see Guide to the Scriptures, "Immortality"; "Eternal Life"; Moses 1:39).

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 66:2, the Lord identifies His "everlasting covenant" as which of the following?
answers: The fulness of my gospel
The law of Moses
The token of the rainbow
The covenant of circumcision
correct_answer: The fulness of my gospel
explanation: D&C 66:2 explicitly equates the everlasting covenant with "the fulness of my gospel."

question_text: In the Lord’s preface to the Doctrine and Covenants (Section 1), what does He say about people and His everlasting covenant?
answers: They have broken it
They have never received it
They have kept it perfectly
It was never offered to them
correct_answer: They have broken it
explanation: D&C 1:15 states that people have "strayed from [His] ordinances, and have broken [His] everlasting covenant."

question_text: Which section of the Doctrine and Covenants teaches about the "new and everlasting covenant of marriage"?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 132
Doctrine and Covenants 76
Doctrine and Covenants 20
Doctrine and Covenants 89
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 132
explanation: D&C 132 contains the revelation on eternal marriage, often called the "new and everlasting covenant of marriage."

question_text: According to the Fourth Article of Faith of the LDS Church, what is listed as the first principle of the Gospel?
answers: Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ
Repentance
Baptism by immersion for the remission of sins
Laying on of hands for the gift of the Holy Ghost
correct_answer: Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ
explanation: Articles of Faith 1:4 states: "We believe that the first principles and ordinances of the Gospel are: first, Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ..."

question_text: In Ether 12:6, what does Moroni teach about when a witness comes to those who exercise faith in Jesus Christ?
answers: Before any trial of faith, as an immediate sign
After the trial of your faith
Only after baptism and confirmation
Only when commanded by a prophet
correct_answer: After the trial of your faith
explanation: Ether 12:6 teaches that "ye receive no witness until after the trial of your faith," emphasizing perseverance in Christ.

question_text: According to LDS scripture, in whose name alone is salvation found, making Him the essential object of saving faith?
answers: Joseph Smith
The Church as an institution
Jesus Christ
Any of the prophets
correct_answer: Jesus Christ
explanation: Acts 4:12 and Mosiah 3:17 affirm that salvation comes in no other name but Jesus Christ, indicating saving faith must be centered in Him.

question_text: According to Latter-day Saint scripture, which two kinds of death entered the world because of the Fall of Adam and Eve?
answers: Physical (temporal) death and spiritual death
Symbolic death and reincarnation
Eternal damnation and loss of agency
Celestial death and terrestrial death
correct_answer: Physical (temporal) death and spiritual death
explanation: LDS scripture teaches the Fall brought both physical (temporal) death and spiritual death (separation from God) into the world (see 2 Nephi 9:6; Alma 12:16; Alma 42:9; Moses 6:48).

question_text: Which statement in the Articles of Faith teaches that individuals are not punished for Adam's transgression?
answers: The Second Article of Faith
The First Article of Faith
The Third Article of Faith
The Tenth Article of Faith
correct_answer: The Second Article of Faith
explanation: Article of Faith 2 states: “We believe that men will be punished for their own sins, and not for Adam’s transgression.”

question_text: According to Moses 5:11, what did Eve say they gained because of the Fall?
answers: The ability to have children and to know good and evil, leading to joy in redemption
Immediate perfection and return to God's presence
Immortality in the Garden without labor
Authority to command all angels
correct_answer: The ability to have children and to know good and evil, leading to joy in redemption
explanation: Moses 5:11 records Eve saying that without their transgression they would not have had seed, nor known good and evil, and would not have known the joy of their redemption.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint doctrine, which ordinance makes it possible for a husband and wife to be married for time and all eternity, binding their family beyond mortality?
answers: Temple sealing (celestial marriage) performed by priesthood authority
Baptism by immersion
The sacrament (Lord's Supper)
Confirmation (gift of the Holy Ghost)
correct_answer: Temple sealing (celestial marriage) performed by priesthood authority
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 132 teaches that marriages sealed by proper priesthood authority in temples can endure beyond death.

question_text: According to the Church’s General Handbook, which day is encouraged to be set aside, where possible, for home-centered gospel learning and family time?
answers: Monday evening
Wednesday evening
Saturday morning
Sunday afternoon
correct_answer: Monday evening
explanation: The General Handbook encourages members to reserve Monday evening for individuals and families to be at home for gospel learning and wholesome activities.

question_text: According to 'The Family: A Proclamation to the World,' what is central to the Creator's plan for the eternal destiny of His children?
answers: The family
Personal wealth
National governments
Academic education
correct_answer: The family
explanation: The Proclamation states that the family is central to God's plan for the eternal destiny of His children.

question_text: Which set correctly lists the four commonly taught types of family councils in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
answers: General (entire family), Executive (parents only), Limited (parents with one child), One-on-one (one parent with one child)
Ward, Stake, Area, General
Patriarchal, Matriarchal, Sibling, Extended
Quorum, Auxiliary, Priesthood, Relief Society
correct_answer: General (entire family), Executive (parents only), Limited (parents with one child), One-on-one (one parent with one child)
explanation: Official Church guidance teaches four types of family councils: general, executive, limited, and one-on-one, used as needed to bless the family.

question_text: According to Church guidance, what is an appropriate purpose of a family council?
answers: To counsel together in prayer, set goals, and address family concerns
To replace private worthiness interviews with a bishop
To make binding administrative decisions for the ward or stake
To conduct disciplinary councils for family members
correct_answer: To counsel together in prayer, set goals, and address family concerns
explanation: Family councils are intended to strengthen the family through discussion, planning, and seeking the Lord’s guidance; they do not replace ecclesiastical interviews or Church disciplinary processes.

question_text: What guidance is given about how often families should hold family councils?
answers: Hold them regularly and as needed to address family matters
Only once per year at the start of the calendar year
No more than once per month and only on Fast Sunday
Only when scheduled by the bishop
correct_answer: Hold them regularly and as needed to address family matters
explanation: Church counsel encourages families to meet in councils regularly and as circumstances require, rather than on a fixed, Church-mandated schedule.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 119, how is tithing defined?
answers: One-tenth of a person's annual interest (increase)
One-twelfth of monthly income
Any amount the bishop assigns annually
One-tenth of gross income including gifts and benefits
correct_answer: One-tenth of a person's annual interest (increase)
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 119:4 defines tithing as "one-tenth of all their interest annually."

question_text: In official Church guidance, how are members counseled to determine the amount of a fast offering?
answers: A generous amount, often at least the value of the two meals not eaten while fasting, as circumstances allow
A fixed 2 percent of income in addition to tithing
An amount equal to one day’s wages
Whatever the ward clerk sets as the standard monthly amount
correct_answer: A generous amount, often at least the value of the two meals not eaten while fasting, as circumstances allow
explanation: Official guidance teaches there is no set percentage; members give a generous fast offering, commonly at least the value of the two missed meals when possible.

question_text: Which guideline is specifically taught in the First Presidency pamphlet “All Is Safely Gathered In: Family Finances”?
answers: Avoid debt; use a budget; and build a financial reserve by saving consistently
Use consumer debt to build credit and invest aggressively
Pay tithing only after all other expenses are covered
Rely on future income rather than savings for emergencies
correct_answer: Avoid debt; use a budget; and build a financial reserve by saving consistently
explanation: The pamphlet counsels families to pay tithes and offerings, avoid debt, create and live by a budget, and build a reserve through regular saving.

question_text: Which revelation records Elijah’s appearance in the Kirtland Temple, where he conferred the sealing keys central to temple and family history work?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 110
Doctrine and Covenants 76
Doctrine and Covenants 124
Joseph Smith—History 1:17 (Pearl of Great Price)
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 110
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 110 describes Elijah appearing on April 3, 1836, and conferring the sealing keys that enable temple and family history work.

question_text: What is the Church’s free, official family history website used to build family trees and submit names for temple ordinances?
answers: FamilySearch.org
Ancestry.com
MyHeritage.com
Findmypast.com
correct_answer: FamilySearch.org
explanation: FamilySearch.org is the Church’s official, free family history platform used by members and the public worldwide.

question_text: According to the Church’s 110-year rule, what is required before submitting a deceased person born within the last 110 years for proxy temple ordinances?
answers: Be an immediate family member or have permission from a close living relative (spouse, adult child, parent, or sibling)
Be a Melchizedek Priesthood holder
Obtain approval from the bishop
No special requirements beyond creating a FamilySearch record
correct_answer: Be an immediate family member or have permission from a close living relative (spouse, adult child, parent, or sibling)
explanation: Church policy requires that for those born within the last 110 years, the submitter must be an immediate family member or have permission from one of the closest living relatives.

question_text: Which day of the week has been designated by the Church as the regular time for Family Home Evening, during which Church units should not schedule activities?
answers: Monday
Tuesday
Sunday
Friday
correct_answer: Monday
explanation: The Church reserves Monday evenings for Family Home Evening and directs that Church activities not be scheduled then.

question_text: In what year did the First Presidency under President Joseph F. Smith first issue a formal letter encouraging families to hold a regular "home evening"?
explanation: A First Presidency letter in 1915 encouraged families to set aside one evening each week for home-centered gospel instruction and activities.

question_text: According to official Church materials, what is the primary purpose of Family Home Evening?
answers: To strengthen families through prayer, scripture study, gospel teaching, and wholesome activities
To replace Sunday worship services with home observance
To conduct neighborhood missionary tracting
To fulfill community service requirements for local schools
correct_answer: To strengthen families through prayer, scripture study, gospel teaching, and wholesome activities
explanation: Official resources teach that Family Home Evening is a weekly time to build faith and family unity through gospel learning and uplifting activities.

question_text: On which day is Fast Sunday generally observed in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
answers: The first Sunday of each month
The last Friday of each month
The second Sunday of each month
Every Sunday
correct_answer: The first Sunday of each month
explanation: Fast Sunday is generally held on the first Sunday of each month, when members fast and the ward holds a fast and testimony meeting. Local leaders may adjust as needed.

question_text: According to Church practice, what does a proper fast typically consist of?
answers: Abstaining from food and drink for two consecutive meals, accompanied by prayer, if health permits
Avoiding meat on Fridays throughout the year
Drinking only water for seven consecutive days
Skipping one meal and refraining from entertainment
correct_answer: Abstaining from food and drink for two consecutive meals, accompanied by prayer, if health permits
explanation: Members are taught to fast by abstaining from food and drink for two consecutive meals and to combine the fast with prayer, as health allows.

question_text: What is the primary purpose of fast offerings in the Church?
answers: To provide for the poor and needy under the direction of the bishop
To fund salaries for local clergy
To pay for temple construction and maintenance
To subsidize recreational activities for youth
correct_answer: To provide for the poor and needy under the direction of the bishop
explanation: Fast offerings are donated funds used by bishops to assist those in need with essential temporal needs in their local units.

question_text: In which section of the Doctrine and Covenants is the First Presidency described as three presiding high priests who form a quorum (the Presidency of the Church)?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 107
Doctrine and Covenants 20
Doctrine and Covenants 121
Doctrine and Covenants 1
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 107
explanation: D&C 107 teaches that three presiding high priests form a quorum—the Presidency of the Church.

question_text: Which statement best describes what happens to the First Presidency when the President of the Church dies?
answers: The First Presidency is dissolved, and the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles presides until the First Presidency is reorganized.
The senior counselor automatically becomes President and retains the existing First Presidency.
The Presiding Bishop becomes interim President until a new First Presidency is called.
The First Presidency continues unchanged and appoints a new President by majority vote.
correct_answer: The First Presidency is dissolved, and the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles presides until the First Presidency is reorganized.
explanation: Upon the President’s death, the First Presidency is dissolved; the Quorum of the Twelve presides until a new First Presidency is organized.

question_text: According to scripture, members of the First Presidency hold which priesthood office?
answers: Presiding high priests in the Melchizedek Priesthood
High priests in the Aaronic Priesthood
Patriarchs in the Patriarchal Priesthood
Deacons in the Aaronic Priesthood
correct_answer: Presiding high priests in the Melchizedek Priesthood
explanation: D&C 107 identifies the Presidency of the Church as three presiding high priests, which is a Melchizedek Priesthood office.

question_text: Which specific scripture prompted Joseph Smith to pray, leading to the First Vision, according to Joseph Smith—History?
answers: James 1:5
Matthew 7:7
John 3:16
Romans 10:9
correct_answer: James 1:5
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:11–13 states that reading James 1:5 moved Joseph to ask God for wisdom in prayer.

question_text: According to the canonical 1838 account in Joseph Smith—History, who appeared to Joseph Smith in the First Vision?
answers: God the Father and Jesus Christ
The angel Moroni
Peter, James, and John
The Holy Ghost alone
correct_answer: God the Father and Jesus Christ
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:17 records that two Personages appeared, and one introduced the other as His Beloved Son.

question_text: What instruction did Joseph Smith receive regarding which church to join during the First Vision?
answers: He was told to join none of them
He was told to join the Methodist Church
He was told to wait ten years before deciding
He was told to start a church immediately
correct_answer: He was told to join none of them
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:19 states he was instructed not to join any of the churches then existing.

question_text: According to the canonized 1838 account in Joseph Smith—History, what instruction did Joseph receive regarding the existing churches?
answers: That he should join none of them
That he must join the Presbyterian Church
That he should immediately establish a church in 1820
That he should wait until age 21 to choose a church
correct_answer: That he should join none of them
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:19 records that he was told to join none of the existing churches.

question_text: How many firsthand accounts by Joseph Smith of the First Vision are known in historical sources?
answers: One (1838 only)
Nine (all by Joseph Smith)
explanation: The Church's Gospel Topics essay identifies four firsthand accounts by Joseph Smith: 1832, 1835, 1838, and 1842.

question_text: In which standard work and passage is the canonized First Vision account found?
answers: Pearl of Great Price, Joseph Smith—History 1:1–20
Doctrine and Covenants 76
Book of Mormon, Introduction
New Testament, Acts 9
correct_answer: Pearl of Great Price, Joseph Smith—History 1:1–20
explanation: The canonized First Vision account is in the Pearl of Great Price as Joseph Smith—History 1:1–20.

question_text: According to the First Presidency’s pamphlet All Is Safely Gathered In: Family Home Storage, what is the recommended first step for families beginning food storage?
answers: Gradually build a three-month supply of foods you normally eat
Immediately store a one-year supply of wheat and dry beans
Focus first on purchasing freeze-dried meals for six months
Defer food storage until all debts are paid
correct_answer: Gradually build a three-month supply of foods you normally eat
explanation: The pamphlet counsels families to begin by gradually building a small supply of everyday foods until they have about three months’ worth.

question_text: According to official Church guidance, approximately how much water per person per day should be stored for emergencies?
answers: 1 gallon (3.8 liters)
2 liters
5 gallons (19 liters)
0.5 gallon (1.9 liters)
correct_answer: 1 gallon (3.8 liters)
explanation: Church guidance on emergency preparation specifies storing about 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water per person per day.

question_text: Per the Church’s longer-term food storage guidelines, which type of rice is recommended for long-term storage?
answers: White (polished) rice
Brown rice
Wild rice
Instant flavored rice
correct_answer: White (polished) rice
explanation: Official storage guidance lists white rice as suitable for long-term storage when properly packaged, whereas brown rice has oils that limit shelf life.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint doctrine, what is meant by "foreordination"?
answers: God's premortal appointment of certain individuals to specific mortal missions, contingent on their agency and faithfulness
The unconditional predestination of all human outcomes regardless of choice
The conferral of priesthood authority after baptism
The sealing of families by priesthood keys in temples
correct_answer: God's premortal appointment of certain individuals to specific mortal missions, contingent on their agency and faithfulness
explanation: Scripture teaches God chose individuals before birth for certain roles (Abraham 3:22–23; Jeremiah 1:5), and that such callings are associated with agency and righteousness (Alma 13:3).

question_text: Which scripture explicitly teaches that some were chosen before birth, including "noble and great ones" whom God would make rulers?
answers: Abraham 3:22–23
Doctrine and Covenants 89
Alma 32:21
Matthew 28:19–20
correct_answer: Abraham 3:22–23
explanation: Abraham 3:22–23 states that "noble and great" spirits were chosen before birth and that God would make them rulers.

question_text: According to Alma 13:3, on what basis were some priests "called and prepared from the foundation of the world"?
answers: Because of their exceeding faith and good works
Solely because of their lineage from Levi
By random selection before mortality
Only after their baptism in mortality
correct_answer: Because of their exceeding faith and good works
explanation: Alma 13:3 says they were called and prepared "on account of their exceeding faith and good works" and still retained agency.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 64:10, what does the Lord require of His disciples regarding forgiveness of others?
answers: Forgive all people
Forgive only those who repent
Forgive up to seventy times seven
Withhold forgiveness to protect justice
correct_answer: Forgive all people
explanation: D&C 64:10 states, "I, the Lord, will forgive whom I will forgive, but of you it is required to forgive all men."

question_text: Which statement aligns with official Church teaching about forgiveness in situations of abuse?
answers: Forgiveness requires victims to stay in harmful relationships to prove faith
Forgiveness means forgetting the abuse and avoiding legal or ecclesiastical help
Forgiveness does not mean condoning abuse; victims should seek safety and support
Only a bishop can grant forgiveness to a victim of abuse
correct_answer: Forgiveness does not mean condoning abuse; victims should seek safety and support
explanation: Official resources teach that forgiving does not mean condoning or remaining in abuse; individuals should ensure safety and seek help (General Handbook; Gospel Topics: "Abuse," "Forgiveness").

question_text: In 3 Nephi 13:14–15, what condition does Jesus teach influences whether the Father will forgive our trespasses?
answers: Whether we fast and pray publicly
Whether we forgive others their trespasses
Whether we pay tithing annually
Whether we make a covenant in the temple
correct_answer: Whether we forgive others their trespasses
explanation: 3 Nephi 13:14–15 (parallel to Matthew 6:14–15) teaches that if we forgive others, the Father will also forgive us; if we do not, He will not.

question_text: According to the Church’s official policy, what is its stance on gambling and lotteries?
answers: The Church opposes gambling in any form, including government-sponsored lotteries
Gambling is acceptable if proceeds go to charity
Members may participate in state lotteries if they pay tithing on winnings
Gambling is a personal choice with no official position
correct_answer: The Church opposes gambling in any form, including government-sponsored lotteries
explanation: Official Church sources state that the Church opposes all forms of gambling, specifically including government-sponsored lotteries.

question_text: Which of the following is explicitly not permitted as a fund-raising method in Church units?
answers: Raffles or lotteries
Bake sales
Car washes
Choir concerts
correct_answer: Raffles or lotteries
explanation: The General Handbook forbids raffles, lotteries, and other games of chance for Church fund-raising activities.

question_text: Which example is identified by official Church sources as a form of gambling members should avoid?
answers: Sports pools
Buying government savings bonds
Playing board games without money involved
Donating to fast offerings
correct_answer: Sports pools
explanation: Church materials list sports pools among forms of gambling members should not participate in.

question_text: According to official Church statements, what is the primary purpose of the temple garment?
answers: A sacred reminder of covenants made in the temple, worn under normal clothing
A uniform required only during Sunday worship
A protective charm guaranteeing physical safety
A cultural symbol worn at personal discretion after baptism
correct_answer: A sacred reminder of covenants made in the temple, worn under normal clothing
explanation: The Church states that the garment is sacred clothing associated with the endowment and serves as a private, personal reminder of temple covenants, worn beneath everyday clothing.

question_text: According to the General Handbook, when are endowed members expected to wear the temple garment?
answers: Day and night as a constant reminder of temple covenants, removing it only for activities where it cannot reasonably be worn
Only while in the temple or on the Sabbath
Only during missionary service
Only during priesthood or Relief Society meetings
correct_answer: Day and night as a constant reminder of temple covenants, removing it only for activities where it cannot reasonably be worn
explanation: The General Handbook counsels endowed members to wear the garment day and night and not remove it for activities that can reasonably be done while wearing it.

question_text: Who is authorized to wear the temple garment, according to official Church sources?
answers: Endowed members of the Church who have received the temple endowment
All baptized members age eight and older
Only holders of the Melchizedek Priesthood
Full-time missionaries regardless of endowment
correct_answer: Endowed members of the Church who have received the temple endowment
explanation: The garment is provided in connection with the temple endowment and is worn by endowed Latter-day Saints.

question_text: According to the Tenth Article of Faith, what does the Church affirm about the gathering of Israel and the Ten Tribes?
answers: That Israel will be literally gathered and the Ten Tribes restored
That the gathering is purely symbolic and the Ten Tribes will not return
That Israel's gathering ended with the return from Babylon
That only Judah will be gathered in the last days
correct_answer: That Israel will be literally gathered and the Ten Tribes restored
explanation: Article of Faith 10 states belief in the literal gathering of Israel and the restoration of the Ten Tribes, along with Zion being built on the American continent.

question_text: In Doctrine and Covenants 110, who committed the keys of the gathering of Israel to Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery in the Kirtland Temple?
answers: Moses
Elijah
Peter
Elias
correct_answer: Moses
explanation: D&C 110:11 records that Moses appeared and committed the keys of the gathering of Israel, while Elias gave the dispensation of the gospel of Abraham and Elijah restored sealing keys.

question_text: According to 3 Nephi 21, what sign did Jesus give that the gathering of Israel had begun?
answers: The coming forth of the Book of Mormon to the Gentiles
The building of Solomon’s Temple in Jerusalem
The end of Roman rule in Judea
The discovery of the lost Ten Tribes’ records
correct_answer: The coming forth of the Book of Mormon to the Gentiles
explanation: In 3 Nephi 21:1–7, Jesus teaches that the coming forth of His words (the Book of Mormon) to the Gentiles is a sign that the Father has commenced to gather Israel.

question_text: Which of the following is specifically named in Doctrine and Covenants 46 as a gift of the Spirit?
answers: Discerning of spirits
Ordination to the Melchizedek Priesthood
Holding a temple recommend
Receiving a patriarchal blessing
correct_answer: Discerning of spirits
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 46:23 lists the discerning of spirits among the gifts of the Spirit.

question_text: According to the Seventh Article of Faith, which of the following are gifts of the Spirit?
answers: Gift of tongues and gift of healing
Tithing and fasting
Baptism and the sacrament
Sealing and patriarchal authority
correct_answer: Gift of tongues and gift of healing
explanation: Articles of Faith 1:7 names the gift of tongues and healing among the gifts of the Spirit.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 46, what is the primary purpose of the gifts of the Spirit?
answers: To benefit and bless the Church and those who love God and keep His commandments
To provide public signs proving the Church’s authority
To guarantee personal salvation regardless of obedience
To replace the need for church leaders and ordinances
correct_answer: To benefit and bless the Church and those who love God and keep His commandments
explanation: D&C 46:9, 12, and 26 teach that gifts are given for the benefit of those who love God and are to profit the Church, not as signs to the unbelieving.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 130:22, which statement correctly describes the nature of the members of the Godhead?
answers: The Father and the Son have bodies of flesh and bones; the Holy Ghost is a personage of Spirit.
All three members of the Godhead are spirits without bodies.
Only the Father has a body; the Son and Holy Ghost do not.
The Father, Son, and Holy Ghost are one being in substance.
correct_answer: The Father and the Son have bodies of flesh and bones; the Holy Ghost is a personage of Spirit.
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 130:22 explicitly states that the Father and the Son have bodies of flesh and bones, and that the Holy Ghost is a personage of Spirit.

question_text: Which statement reflects the First Article of Faith regarding the Godhead?
answers: Latter-day Saints believe in God, the Eternal Father, in His Son Jesus Christ, and in the Holy Ghost.
Latter-day Saints believe only in God the Father and Jesus Christ.
Latter-day Saints worship a single being who is simultaneously Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.
Latter-day Saints include Heavenly Mother as a member of the Godhead in the Articles of Faith.
correct_answer: Latter-day Saints believe in God, the Eternal Father, in His Son Jesus Christ, and in the Holy Ghost.
explanation: The First Article of Faith declares belief in God the Eternal Father, His Son Jesus Christ, and the Holy Ghost as distinct members.

question_text: According to Jesus’ instruction in the Book of Mormon, to whom should prayers be addressed?
answers: To the Father, in the name of Jesus Christ.
Directly to Jesus Christ without addressing the Father.
To the Holy Ghost, who then relays them to the Father.
To any member of the Godhead interchangeably.
correct_answer: To the Father, in the name of Jesus Christ.
explanation: 3 Nephi 18:19 and 2 Nephi 32:9 instruct disciples to pray unto the Father in the name of Christ; see also D&C 46:30.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 130:22, what is taught about the nature of God the Father?
answers: He has a body of flesh and bones as tangible as man’s
He is a spirit without body parts or passions
He is an impersonal cosmic force
He and the Holy Ghost share one physical body
correct_answer: He has a body of flesh and bones as tangible as man’s
explanation: D&C 130:22 states that the Father has a body of flesh and bones as tangible as man’s, distinguishing Him from the Holy Ghost, who is a personage of Spirit.

question_text: In Joseph Smith—History 1:17, what key truth about God the Father and Jesus Christ is revealed?
answers: They are two distinct Personages
They are the same being manifest in different modes
The Father cannot be seen by mortals
Only angels, not Deity, appear to prophets
correct_answer: They are two distinct Personages
explanation: Joseph Smith’s First Vision account records the appearance of the Father and the Son as two separate, distinct Personages.

question_text: According to Latter-day Saint scripture and practice, to whom are prayers directed?
answers: To God the Father, in the name of Jesus Christ
Directly to Jesus Christ without addressing the Father
To the Holy Ghost for revelation
To deceased ancestors as intercessors
correct_answer: To God the Father, in the name of Jesus Christ
explanation: Scriptures teach to pray to the Father in Christ’s name (e.g., Matthew 6:9; John 16:23; 3 Nephi 18:19), and Church practice follows this pattern.

question_text: According to Joseph Smith—History, which angel delivered the gold plates to Joseph Smith?
answers: Moroni
Nephi
Mormon
Gabriel
correct_answer: Moroni
explanation: Joseph Smith—History identifies the angel as Moroni, who informed Joseph about the record and later entrusted the plates to him (JS—H 1:33–35, 1:59).

question_text: In the Testimony of the Eight Witnesses printed in the Book of Mormon, how do the witnesses describe the appearance of the plates?
answers: They had the appearance of gold.
They were made of silver.
They were carved from brass.
They were wood covered in paint.
correct_answer: They had the appearance of gold.
explanation: The Eight Witnesses state they saw and handled the plates, which had 'the appearance of gold.'

question_text: On what date did Joseph Smith obtain the gold plates from the hill, according to Joseph Smith—History?
answers: September 22, 1827
April 6, 1830
September 21, 1823
correct_answer: September 22, 1827
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:59 records that Joseph obtained the plates on September 22, 1827.

question_text: Which set lists the first principles and ordinances of the Gospel as stated in the Fourth Article of Faith?
answers: Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism by immersion for the remission of sins, and laying on of hands for the gift of the Holy Ghost
Obedience, tithing, temple marriage, and missionary service
Prayer, scripture study, Sabbath observance, and fasting
Faith, hope, charity, and patience
correct_answer: Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism by immersion for the remission of sins, and laying on of hands for the gift of the Holy Ghost
explanation: Article of Faith 4 lists these as the first principles and ordinances of the Gospel (Pearl of Great Price, Articles of Faith 1:4).

question_text: According to Jesus’s own definition in 3 Nephi 27:13–21, which option best summarizes His gospel?
answers: That He did the Father’s will, was lifted up upon the cross, and that we must have faith in Him, repent, be baptized, receive the Holy Ghost, and endure to the end to be saved
That salvation comes through strict observance of the law of Moses and animal sacrifice
That temple ordinances alone save regardless of repentance or obedience
That only ordained apostles can be saved, regardless of personal faith
correct_answer: That He did the Father’s will, was lifted up upon the cross, and that we must have faith in Him, repent, be baptized, receive the Holy Ghost, and endure to the end to be saved
explanation: In 3 Nephi 27:13–21, Jesus defines His gospel, emphasizing His atoning sacrifice and the requirements of faith, repentance, baptism, reception of the Holy Ghost, and enduring to the end.

question_text: Which weekly ordinance instituted by Jesus helps Latter-day Saints renew their commitment to live the gospel?
answers: The sacrament of the Lord’s Supper (bread and water)
A weekly washing of feet
An annual Passover meal
Private confession to a priest
correct_answer: The sacrament of the Lord’s Supper (bread and water)
explanation: The sacrament was instituted by Jesus (Luke 22:19–20) and is administered in the Church as outlined in Doctrine and Covenants 20:75–79 and 3 Nephi 18.

question_text: According to 2 Nephi 2:8, by what means can anyone dwell in the presence of God?
answers: Through the merits, and mercy, and grace of the Holy Messiah
Through strict observance of the Law of Moses alone
Through personal righteousness without divine aid
Through priesthood ordinances without faith
correct_answer: Through the merits, and mercy, and grace of the Holy Messiah
explanation: 2 Nephi 2:8 teaches that no flesh can dwell in God's presence except through the merits, mercy, and grace of the Holy Messiah.

question_text: Which scripture contains the phrase, "for we know that it is by grace that we are saved, after all we can do"?
answers: 2 Nephi 25:23
Alma 34:15
Doctrine and Covenants 76:40
Romans 5:2
correct_answer: 2 Nephi 25:23
explanation: The exact phrase appears in 2 Nephi 25:23 in the Book of Mormon.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 20:30–31, which blessings come through the grace of Jesus Christ?
answers: Justification and sanctification
Glorification and exaltation
Resurrection and translation
Prophecy and revelation
correct_answer: Justification and sanctification
explanation: D&C 20:30–31 explicitly states that justification and sanctification come through the grace of Jesus Christ.

question_text: Which passage in the Doctrine and Covenants explicitly commands, "Thou shalt thank the Lord thy God in all things"?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 59:7
Doctrine and Covenants 20:77
Doctrine and Covenants 89:4
Doctrine and Covenants 121:7
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 59:7
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 59:7 directly commands believers to thank the Lord in all things.

question_text: Which Book of Mormon verse includes the counsel, "when thou risest in the morning let thy heart be full of thanks unto God"?
answers: Alma 37:37
2 Nephi 32:9
Mosiah 2:20
Moroni 10:4
correct_answer: Alma 37:37
explanation: Alma 37:37 counsels to counsel with the Lord and specifically includes showing gratitude upon rising in the morning.

question_text: According to 1 Thessalonians 5:18, what is God's will regarding gratitude?
answers: That we give thanks in everything
That we offer thanks only on the Sabbath
That gratitude be expressed only after receiving blessings
That thanks be given only under the Mosaic law
correct_answer: That we give thanks in everything
explanation: 1 Thessalonians 5:18 states, "In every thing give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you."

question_text: Which Latter-day Saint scripture passage contains the covenant to "mourn with those that mourn" and "comfort those that stand in need of comfort"?
answers: Mosiah 18:8-9
Doctrine and Covenants 121:7-8
Matthew 5:4
correct_answer: Mosiah 18:8-9
explanation: Mosiah 18:8-9 records Alma’s teaching on the baptismal covenant, which includes mourning with those that mourn and comforting those in need.

question_text: Which Church leader’s vision, canonized as Doctrine and Covenants 138, teaches about the preaching of the gospel to the dead and offers comfort concerning those who have died?
answers: Joseph F. Smith
Joseph Smith
Brigham Young
Wilford Woodruff
correct_answer: Joseph F. Smith
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 138 is President Joseph F. Smith’s 1918 vision of the redemption of the dead, describing the Lord’s work among those in the spirit world.

question_text: According to the Church Handbook, who conducts and directs a funeral service held in a Latter-day Saint meetinghouse?
answers: The bishop (or branch president)
The family of the deceased
The Relief Society president
The stake president
correct_answer: The bishop (or branch president)
explanation: The General Handbook states that the bishop (or branch president) oversees, conducts, and directs funeral services held in the meetinghouse.

question_text: Which Book of Mormon verse declares, "wickedness never was happiness"?
answers: Alma 41:10
2 Nephi 2:25
Mosiah 2:41
Alma 42:8
correct_answer: Alma 41:10
explanation: Alma 41:10 explicitly states the phrase "wickedness never was happiness," contrasting happiness with misery.

question_text: Where in the Book of Mormon does King Benjamin teach of the "blessed and happy state" of the obedient and "never-ending happiness"?
answers: Mosiah 2:41
Alma 36:3
Ether 12:27
correct_answer: Mosiah 2:41
explanation: Mosiah 2:41 promises that those who keep the commandments enjoy a "blessed and happy state" and "never-ending happiness."

question_text: According to The Family: A Proclamation to the World, happiness in family life is most likely to be achieved when founded upon what?
answers: The teachings of the Lord Jesus Christ
Shared recreational activities
Financial stability
Cultural traditions
correct_answer: The teachings of the Lord Jesus Christ
explanation: The Proclamation states, "Happiness in family life is most likely to be achieved when founded upon the teachings of the Lord Jesus Christ."

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 89 (the Word of Wisdom), which item is declared “not for the body, neither for the belly”?
answers: Tobacco
Fish
Herbs
Grains
correct_answer: Tobacco
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 89:8 states that tobacco is not for the body or belly and is not good for man.

question_text: What is the Church’s official stance on immunizations for members?
answers: The Church encourages vaccinations and immunizations to protect health.
The Church prohibits vaccinations for religious reasons.
The Church teaches that vaccinations violate the Word of Wisdom.
The Church takes no position and discourages members from being vaccinated.
correct_answer: The Church encourages vaccinations and immunizations to protect health.
explanation: The General Handbook states that the Church encourages members to safeguard their health through immunizations.

question_text: Under which Church President did adherence to the Word of Wisdom become a standard requirement for temple recommends?
answers: Heber J. Grant
Brigham Young
Joseph F. Smith
Spencer W. Kimball
correct_answer: Heber J. Grant
explanation: In the early 20th century, particularly under President Heber J. Grant, observance of the Word of Wisdom became a requirement for temple recommends.

question_text: Which passage of Latter-day Saint canon contains Jesus's statement, "In my Father's house are many mansions," referring to the heavenly dwelling place?
answers: John 14:2 in the New Testament
Doctrine and Covenants 76:50–70
Moroni 10:3–5
Articles of Faith 1:3
correct_answer: John 14:2 in the New Testament
explanation: John 14:2 records Jesus teaching about many mansions in the Father's house, a key statement about heaven accepted in Latter-day Saint canon.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 76 and 1 Corinthians 15, what are the names of the three degrees of heavenly glory?
answers: Celestial, Terrestrial, Telestial
Seraphic, Cherubic, Angelic
Paradise, Prison, Outer Darkness
Zion, Salem, Enoch
correct_answer: Celestial, Terrestrial, Telestial
explanation: D&C 76 names the three degrees of glory as celestial, terrestrial, and telestial, corresponding to Paul's sun, moon, and stars analogy in 1 Corinthians 15.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint doctrine, where do spirits reside between death and resurrection before assignment to a kingdom of heavenly glory?
answers: The spirit world (paradise or spirit prison)
The celestial kingdom
Outer darkness with sons of perdition
On the earth as resurrected beings
correct_answer: The spirit world (paradise or spirit prison)
explanation: Alma 40:11–14 and D&C 138 teach that after death, spirits go to the spirit world—paradise or spirit prison—pending resurrection and final judgment.

question_text: Which official Church document explicitly teaches that "all human beings—male and female—are beloved spirit sons and daughters of heavenly parents"?
answers: The Family: A Proclamation to the World (1995)
The Articles of Faith
The Living Christ: The Testimony of the Apostles (2000)
The Book of Mormon, Title Page
correct_answer: The Family: A Proclamation to the World (1995)
explanation: The 1995 Proclamation states that all people are beloved spirit children of heavenly parents, expressing the doctrine clearly and officially.

question_text: According to official Church teaching, to whom should members address their prayers?
answers: Heavenly Father, in the name of Jesus Christ
Heavenly Mother
Heavenly Parents collectively
Any member of the Godhead
correct_answer: Heavenly Father, in the name of Jesus Christ
explanation: Official teachings state that prayers are addressed to Heavenly Father in the name of Jesus Christ; Latter-day Saints do not pray to Heavenly Mother.

question_text: Which 1845 hymn by Eliza R. Snow explicitly teaches the existence of a Mother in Heaven, as acknowledged in the Church’s Gospel Topics essay?
answers: O My Father
Praise to the Man
How Great Thou Art
The Spirit of God
correct_answer: O My Father
explanation: Eliza R. Snow's hymn "O My Father" includes the line that when we go home, we will see our Father and Mother there, reflecting belief in a Heavenly Mother.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint teachings, the scriptural term "hell" can refer to which state(s) after death?
answers: A temporary spirit world "prison" for the unrepentant and a final "outer darkness" for sons of perdition
A single eternal place where all non-Christians suffer forever
A temporary purification fire required for everyone before entering heaven
A symbolic concept only, with no actual state or location
correct_answer: A temporary spirit world "prison" for the unrepentant and a final "outer darkness" for sons of perdition
explanation: Scripture teaches preaching to spirits in prison (1 Peter 3:19; 4:6; D&C 138) and a final destiny for the sons of perdition (D&C 76), often referred to as outer darkness.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 76, who are ultimately consigned to suffer with the devil and his angels after the Final Judgment?
answers: The sons of perdition who deny the Holy Ghost
All who never joined the Church in mortality
Those assigned to the telestial kingdom
All who committed serious sins but later repented
correct_answer: The sons of perdition who deny the Holy Ghost
explanation: D&C 76:31–38, 43–49 teaches that only the sons of perdition are not saved in a degree of glory and suffer everlasting punishment with the devil and his angels.

question_text: What does Doctrine and Covenants 19 teach about the phrase "endless punishment"?
answers: It is God's punishment; "Endless" is a name-title of God, not a guarantee of unending duration in every case
It means punishment for exactly 1,000 years
It applies only to those living before Christ
It proves that all punishment after death is absolutely without end for everyone
correct_answer: It is God's punishment; "Endless" is a name-title of God, not a guarantee of unending duration in every case
explanation: D&C 19:6–12 explains that "Endless" and "Eternal" are names of God; therefore "endless punishment" means God's punishment and does not always indicate duration without end.

question_text: In The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, how many members comprise a stake high council?
answers: Twelve high councilors
Seventy members
Fifteen members
Twenty-four high councilors
correct_answer: Twelve high councilors
explanation: Each stake has a high council of 12 high councilors who serve under the direction of the stake presidency (see General Handbook).

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 102, what was the primary purpose of the standing high council organized in Kirtland?
answers: To settle important difficulties in the Church that could not be resolved by lower councils
To direct worldwide missionary work
To supervise temple ordinances
To publish Church periodicals
correct_answer: To settle important difficulties in the Church that could not be resolved by lower councils
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 102 states that the high council was appointed to settle important difficulties that could not be satisfactorily resolved by the Church or the bishop’s council.

question_text: When was the first high council of the Church organized at Kirtland, Ohio?
answers: February 17, 1834
April 6, 1830
January 25, 1832
March 27, 1836
correct_answer: February 17, 1834
explanation: The minutes now recorded in Doctrine and Covenants 102 note the organization of the first high council on February 17, 1834, in Kirtland, Ohio.

question_text: In Latter-day Saint doctrine, the office of High Priest belongs to which priesthood?
answers: Aaronic Priesthood
Melchizedek Priesthood
Patriarchal Priesthood
Levitical Priesthood
correct_answer: Melchizedek Priesthood
explanation: High Priest is an office in the Melchizedek Priesthood, as taught in Doctrine and Covenants 107.

question_text: Since the 2018 restructuring of Melchizedek Priesthood quorums, to which quorum do most high priests in a ward belong (unless they are currently serving in a stake presidency, high council, or bishopric)?
answers: Ward High Priests Group
Elders Quorum
Stake Seventies Quorum
Relief Society
correct_answer: Elders Quorum
explanation: In 2018, the Church discontinued ward high priests groups; high priests not serving in specified leadership roles are members of the elders quorum. A stake high priests quorum includes those in the stake presidency, high council, and bishoprics.

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 68 and 107, if a man is not a literal descendant of Aaron, what priesthood office must he hold to serve as a bishop?
answers: Seventy
Patriarch
High Priest
Priest
correct_answer: High Priest
explanation: D&C 68:19–20 and 107:15–17 teach that unless he is a literal descendant of Aaron, a bishop is to be chosen from the High Priesthood (a high priest in the Melchizedek Priesthood).

question_text: According to Doctrine and Covenants 130:22, what is the nature of the Holy Ghost?
answers: A personage of spirit without a body of flesh and bones
A resurrected being with a glorified body of flesh and bone
An impersonal force that permeates the universe
The premortal Jesus Christ taking spirit form
correct_answer: A personage of spirit without a body of flesh and bones
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 130:22 states that the Holy Ghost is a personage of spirit and does not have a body of flesh and bones.

question_text: In LDS practice, how is the Gift of the Holy Ghost received after baptism?
answers: By the laying on of hands by those with authority (confirmation)
By private prayer alone without any ordinance
Automatically at the moment of water baptism
Through infant christening by any Christian minister
correct_answer: By the laying on of hands by those with authority (confirmation)
explanation: The New Testament shows the gift was given by laying on of hands (Acts 8:14–17), and modern revelation commands confirmation by those with authority (D&C 20:41; Articles of Faith 1:4).

question_text: Which is a primary role of the Holy Ghost taught in LDS scripture?
answers: To testify of the Father and the Son and reveal truth
To preside over all priesthood quorums on earth
To take a mortal body to atone for sin
To coerce belief by removing agency
correct_answer: To testify of the Father and the Son and reveal truth
explanation: Jesus taught that the Holy Ghost testifies of Him (John 15:26). The Book of Mormon teaches that by the power of the Holy Ghost we may know the truth of all things (Moroni 10:5).

question_text: According to the Church’s General Handbook, which day of the week is reserved for home evening and should not be used for stake or ward activities?
answers: Monday
Tuesday
Friday
Sunday
correct_answer: Monday
explanation: The General Handbook instructs that Monday evenings are reserved for home evening, and Church activities should not be scheduled then.

question_text: In which year did the First Presidency first issue a formal letter encouraging Latter-day Saints to hold weekly home evenings?
explanation: A First Presidency letter under President Joseph F. Smith in 1915 formally encouraged weekly home evening, promising spiritual blessings to participating families.

question_text: Who is encouraged by Church leaders to hold home evening?
answers: Only families with children at home
All members, regardless of family circumstances
Only married couples
Only those with ministering assignments
correct_answer: All members, regardless of family circumstances
explanation: Church resources teach that home evening is for everyone—individuals, couples, and families—and can be adapted to any household situation.

question_text: According to the Doctrine and Covenants, which verse explicitly commands, "Thou shalt not lie"?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 42:21
Doctrine and Covenants 59:23
Articles of Faith 3
Moses 1:39
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 42:21
explanation: Doctrine and Covenants 42:21 states, "Thou shalt not lie; he that lieth and will not repent shall be cast out."

question_text: Which Article of Faith explicitly affirms the principle of being "honest"?
answers: Thirteenth Article of Faith
Seventh Article of Faith
Eleventh Article of Faith
First Article of Faith
correct_answer: Thirteenth Article of Faith
explanation: The Thirteenth Article of Faith begins, "We believe in being honest, true, chaste, benevolent, virtuous, and in doing good to all men."

question_text: In the official temple recommend interview, which of the following personal conduct standards is specifically addressed?
answers: Honesty
Political party membership
Academic degree
Dietary preference (e.g., vegetarian/vegan)
correct_answer: Honesty
explanation: The Church’s General Handbook (26.3.1) includes a question about honesty in the temple recommend interview.

question_text: In 2 Nephi 31:20, as disciples "press forward," what description of hope are they counseled to have?
answers: a perfect brightness of hope
a faint glimmer of hope
a reasonable degree of hope
a cautious expectation of hope
correct_answer: a perfect brightness of hope
explanation: 2 Nephi 31:20 teaches to press forward with a steadfastness in Christ, having a perfect brightness of hope.

question_text: According to Ether 12:4, what does hope (which comes of faith) do for the souls of men?
answers: It becomes an anchor to their souls, making them sure and steadfast
It removes all opposition and trials
It guarantees temporal prosperity
It eliminates the need for works
correct_answer: It becomes an anchor to their souls, making them sure and steadfast
explanation: Ether 12:4 states that hope comes of faith and makes an anchor to the souls of men, making them sure and steadfast.

question_text: In Moroni 7:41, what are believers taught to hope for through the Atonement of Christ?
answers: To be raised unto eternal life by the power of the Resurrection
To receive worldly acclaim and success
To avoid all suffering in mortality
To be translated without death
correct_answer: To be raised unto eternal life by the power of the Resurrection
explanation: Moroni 7:41 teaches to have hope through the Atonement of Christ and the power of His Resurrection to be raised unto life eternal.

question_text: Which scripture contains the Lord's promise, 'Be thou humble; and the Lord thy God shall lead thee by the hand, and give thee answer to thy prayers'?
answers: Doctrine and Covenants 112:10
James 4:10
Mosiah 3:19
Doctrine and Covenants 121:41
correct_answer: Doctrine and Covenants 112:10
explanation: The exact wording appears in Doctrine and Covenants 112:10; the other passages discuss humility but do not contain this specific promise.

question_text: According to Alma 32, who is described as 'more blessed' in relation to humility?
answers: Those who humble themselves because of the word
Those compelled to be humble because of poverty
Those who receive a sign before believing
Those who hold priesthood office
correct_answer: Those who humble themselves because of the word
explanation: Alma 32:14–16 teaches that while those compelled to be humble can be blessed, those who choose to humble themselves because of the word are 'more blessed.'

question_text: According to the Church’s Gospel Topics entry on 'Humility,' which statement best defines humility?
answers: Recognizing our dependence on the Lord and our constant need for His support
Considering oneself less talented than others
Avoiding leadership and public service
Publicly denying personal accomplishments
correct_answer: Recognizing our dependence on the Lord and our constant need for His support
explanation: The Gospel Topics entry defines humility as gratefully recognizing our dependence on God and our ongoing need for His help.

question_text: According to Latter-day Saint scripture and official teachings, which description best states Jesus Christ’s relationship to God the Father?
answers: He is the Only Begotten Son of the Father in the flesh
He is an exalted angel created by the Father
He is merely a prophet and moral teacher, not divine
He is the same person as the Father with no distinct personhood
correct_answer: He is the Only Begotten Son of the Father in the flesh
explanation: Scripture affirms Jesus Christ is the Only Begotten Son of the Father (e.g., John 3:16; D&C 93:21), distinct in person from the Father.

question_text: In the Book of Mormon account of the resurrected Christ’s ministry to the Nephites, where did He first appear to the multitude?
answers: At the hill Cumorah
At the temple in the land Bountiful
On the banks of the river Sidon
In the city palace at Zarahemla
correct_answer: At the temple in the land Bountiful
explanation: 3 Nephi 11:1–10 records that the resurrected Jesus Christ appeared to the people gathered at the temple in the land Bountiful.

question_text: According to the sacrament prayers recorded in Doctrine and Covenants 20:77, 79 and Moroni 4–5, what do Church members covenant to do in remembrance of Jesus Christ?
answers: Pay tithing and fast monthly
Take upon them the name of Jesus Christ, always remember Him, and keep His commandments
Perform temple ordinances for their ancestors
Confess sins to a bishop and serve a full-time mission
correct_answer: Take upon them the name of Jesus Christ, always remember Him, and keep His commandments
explanation: The sacrament prayers specify these three promises made in remembrance of Jesus Christ.

question_text: In what year did Joseph Smith report experiencing the First Vision?
explanation: Joseph Smith—History 1:14 states the First Vision occurred in the spring of 1820.

question_text: According to the Book of Mormon title page, by what means did Joseph Smith translate the record?
answers: By the gift and power of God
By studying Hebrew and Egyptian
By comparing Latin manuscripts
By automatic writing without divine aid
correct_answer: By the gift and power of God
explanation: The Book of Mormon title page and Joseph Smith—History 1:62 affirm it was translated “by the gift and power of God.”

question_text: Where was Joseph Smith killed (martyred) in 1844?
answers: Carthage Jail, Illinois
